China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Anyang Normal University, Anyang, Henan 455000, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Anyang Normal University Anyang Henan 455000 PR China A series of novel nanosized x-ZF/ZM-y zeolites for glycerol to aromatics (GTA) were synthesized by using ZIF-8 as a template. The crystallization time and ZIF-8 dosage were systematically studied to clarify the crystallization process, structural characteristics and physicochemical properties of the prepared x-ZF/ZM-y. The results indicated that the growth of x-ZF/ZM-y zeolites involved two stages: attachment-impregnation and crystallization. The addition of ZIF-8 could introduce the active Zn species (ZnOH+) and induce the formation of smaller HZSM-5 nanocrystals in x-ZF/ZM-y, which could effectively facilitate the dehydrogenation-aromatization and aldol condensation steps in GTA and enhance the coke resistance. Furthermore, the ZIF-8 dosage had important influences on the catalytic performances of x-ZF/ZM-y. In particular, the 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 with 0.45 g ZIF-8 dosage and 48 h crystallization time all existed as nanocrystals of 20–40 nm, and possessed a proper redistribution of acid sites, resulting in 59.5% total aromatics yield and 11 h catalyst lifetime over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 owing to the synergistic effect among the ZnOH+, inter-crystalline mesopores and HZSM-5 nanocrystals. Graphical Abstract The best 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity (59.5% aromatics yield) as well as high catalytic stability (11 h lifetime) in GTA reaction for the synergistic effect among active Zn species (ZnOH+), inter-crystalline mesopores and HZSM-5 nanocrystals. ga1 Keywords Glycerol to aromatics Nanosized HZSM-5 zeolite ZIF-8 Coke formation 1 Introduction Due to the rising environmental concerns and decreasing reserved fossil energy, researchers from industry and academia have payed rapid growing attention to the development of sustainable bioenergy recently [1–3]. Owing to its abundant source, environmental friendliness and comparable consumption performances with diesel, biodiesel is regarded as a promising biomass resource which could replace certain amounts of nonrenewable fossil fuels [4]. Nevertheless, a large quantity of crude glycerol by-product (10 wt% of overall production) was formed during the production of biodiesel through catalyzed transesterification process of natural oils/animal fats with short-chin alcohol, which resulted in a severe surplus in glycerol market and a significant decline of the profit in biodiesel industry [5]. As a commercially interesting and effective strategy, the reaction of glycerol to aromatics (GTA) could directly transform the cheap glycerol by-product into high value-added aromatics, especially for benzene, toluene and xylene (BTX), improving the economic benefits of biodiesel industry by fully utilization of crude glycerol, meanwhile providing an alternatively sustainable process that mainly depended on fossil-based procedures. HZSM-5 was the most promising catalyst for aromatization reaction due to its shape selective pore structure for light aromatics, favorable thermal stability and suitable acidic property [6–10]. However, the further application of conventional bare HZSM-5 in GTA reaction was severely limited by its poor catalytic activity and stability for lacking of specific active sites and diffusion restriction of micropores. In order to improve the catalytic performances in aromatization, several dehydrogenation or aromatization-functional promoters (such as Zn, Ga, Sn, Ag and Pt) were introduced to the HZSM-5 zeolite [2,11–14]. For example, in our previous work, a 47.3% aromatics yield was obtained over Zn/HZSM-5(PM) prepared by physical mixing of HZSM-5 and ZnO powder in GTA reaction, which was much higher than that over bare HZSM-5 (28.6%) [15]. Niu and co-workers found that the introduction method of Zn species might have important influences on the Zn state, acidic properties and catalytic performances of the Zn-modified HZSM-5 in methanol to aromatics (MTA) reaction [16]. In addition, the design of hierarchical HZSM-5 by incorporation of mesopores in the microporous zeolite was an effective way to improve the molecular diffusion and catalytic stability of conventional HZSM-5 [17–20]. Wang and co-workers prepared series of hierarchical HZSM-5 by post-treatment of HZSM-5 in different alkaline aqueous solutions, and found the aromatization performances of these hierarchical HZSM-5 was superior than conventional HZSM-5 [21]. However, some concomitant structure destroy and uncontrolled acidity alteration were always observed in the hierarchical zeolite during the post-treatment process, which would suffer from confusions in deeply understanding the structure-activity relationships of the prepared catalysts. Besides, the hierarchical HZSM-5 could also be synthesized by introduction of a mesoporous template, such as carbon black, CaCO3 and carbon aerogel, in the synthesis process [19,22,23]. Nevertheless, although the catalytic stabilities were significantly enhanced by the introduced mesopores, the catalytic activities of these hierarchical HZSM-5 catalysts were not obviously improved due to the absence of added active sites. Nanosized HZSM-5 possessed shorter diffusion path length, larger surface area and more accessible active sites compared to conventional microsized HZSM-5 due to its smaller nanocrystalline size, and consequently attracted extensive attentions as catalyst for reactions involving bulky molecules, such as polymers cracking, biomass pyrolysis and aromatics production [24–27]. Ni and co-workers prepared the H[Zn,Al]ZSM-5 zeolite composed of aggregates of 250 nm × 50 nm × 25 nm nanocrystals with about 2.1 nm inter-crystal voids by direct introduction of Zn into the zeolite framework, and found the catalyst lifetime of the resultant nanosized catalyst was much longer than the microsized Zn/HZSM-5 prepared by Zn impregnation in MTA reaction, which was attributed to the shorter diffusion path in H[Zn,Al]ZSM-5 which could enhance the mass transfer of bulky molecules and suppress the accumulation of coke precursor in micropores, thereby improving the catalytic stability [28]. In addition, Kim and co-workers obtained a series of nanocrystalline HZSM-5 zeolites with different crystallite size (2–300 nm) by using gemini-surfactants having different alkyl chain lengths, and found the acidic properties and catalytic performances were significantly influenced by the crystallite size of nanosized HZSM-5 [29]. It suggested that the crystallite size, physicochemical properties and subsequent catalytic performances of nanosized HZSM-5 could be regulated by tuning the synthesis conditions or the added structure-directing agent. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) containing zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) have unique characteristics such as tailorable structures, controlled porosity, high surface area, and fascinating physicochemical properties [30,31], as a result, they are not only applied in gas sorption/storage, separation, conductivity, catalysis and sensors [32–35], but also recently emerge as novel precursor or template for synthesis of HZSM-5 zeolite [15,36]. In our previous work, a highly active and stable Zn-containing hierarchical Zn@C/HZSM-5 catalyst was prepared by addition of a Zn@C porous carbon mesoporous template derived from ZIF-8 in the zeolite synthesis process, which exhibited superior catalytic activity and stability compared with conventional HZSM-5 in the GTA reaction owing to the simultaneous introduction of ZnOH+ species and intra-crystalline mesopores [15]. In addition, Zang and co-workers directly synthesized Zn-incorporated nanosized HZSM-5 zeolites by using ZIF-8 as template via a steam-assisted conversion procedure, and found that the resultant catalyst showed a high catalytic activity and H2 yield as well as outstanding catalytic stability in dimethyl ether steam reforming (DME SR) reaction [36]. However, a more widely used hydrothermal synthesis method for HZSM-5 was not involved, and the essential active sites in the catalyst were not clearly discriminated in this work. Moreover, the crucial roles of crystallite size and mesopores in the resultant nanosized catalyst were also not thoroughly discussed, which was very important for catalytic reactions involving bulky molecules. In the present work, we introduced ZIF-8 template into the zeolite synthesis process, and thus prepared a series of nanosized x-ZF/ZM-y catalysts, which simultaneously possessed active Zn species, small nanocrystals and inter-crystalline mesopores. The as-synthesized x-ZF/ZM-y catalysts exhibited outstanding catalytic activities and high catalytic stabilities compared with conventional HZSM-5 in the GTA reaction. Moreover, in order to further explore the role of ZIF-8 template, the effects of crystallization time and ZIF-8 dosage on the Zn state, crystallite size, morphology, inter-crystalline mesopores, acidic properties and the subsequent catalytic performances of x-ZF/ZM-y were studied in detail. Finally, the 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 with 0.45 g ZIF-8 addition and 48 h crystallization time showed superior catalytic performances, and thus the deactivation process as well as the catalytic mechanism were thoroughly investigated to further clarify the synergetic effect of the active Zn species, inter-crystalline mesopores and HZSM-5 nanocrystals in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the purchased chemicals in this work were analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. Synthesis of ZIF-8: ZIF-8 was prepared referring to the literature with minor modifications [37]. Typically, 2.38 g of Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O was dissolved in 12.0 mL deionized water. 1.32 g of 2-methylimidazole (C4H6O) was dissolved in 15.04 g ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH, 25.0–28.0 wt%) under stirring. Then, the Zinc nitrate aqueous and 2-methylimidazole solution were mixed together and stirred at 25 °C for 5 h. Finally, the prepared ZIF-8 was obtained by repetitive centrifugation and washing with deionized water until neutral, followed by drying at 60 °C for 12 h. Synthesis of x-ZF/ZM-y: In a typical synthesis, 0.56 g of aluminum isopropoxide (AIP, 25.0 wt% Al2O3) was dissolved in 27.9 g of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25.0 wt% aqueous solution) under sufficient stirring at 25 °C for 1 h. Then, 7.5 mL deionized water was added into the above solution and stirred for another 1 h. After that, 28.6 g of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 28.0 wt% SiO2) was added dropwise under vigorous stirring during 2 h. The molar composition of the resulting mixture was 100 SiO2: 1 Al2O3: 25 TPAOH: 1250 H2O. Subsequently, the mixture was heated to 40 °C and stirred for 5 h, followed by the addition of x g ZIF-8 and 18.0 mL deionized water. After continuously stirring at 40 °C for another 24 h, the resulting gel was transferred into an autoclave with Teflon-lining and hydrothermal treated at 170 °C for y h. The resultant white solid was obtained by repetitive centrifugation and washing with deionized water until neutral. Finally, the prepared catalysts were acquired after drying at 110 °C overnight and subsequent calcination in air at 550 °C for 6 h, and they were denoted as x-ZF/ZM-y, where x referred to the amount of ZIF-8 template and y referred to the crystallization time of zeolite (x = 0.3, 0.45, 0.6; y = 1, 3, 5, 12, 24, 36, 48, 60). Synthesis of conventional HZSM-5: For comparison, the conventional HZSM-5 was prepared by a similar way with x-ZF/ZM-y in the absence of ZIF-8 template. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The bulk Si/Al ratio and actual Zn content of the prepared catalysts were measured by optical emission spectrometry with inductively coupled plasma (ICP-OES) using an Agilent 730. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of the catalyst were collected on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer (Utima IV) equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) in the 2θ range of 5–50°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were recorded on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα radiation, and the Zn 2p2/3 spectra were collected in the range of 1019.0–1028.0 eV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the catalysts were taken on a FEI instrument (Tecnai G2 20). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were determined at − 196 °C on a Beishide adsorption analyzer (3 H-2000). Prior to the measurement, the samples were degassed under high vacuum at 200 °C for 12 h. The acid strength and acid amount were determined by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) on a Xianquan automated adsorption system (TP-5076) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Typically, 100 mg of catalyst was loaded in a horizontal quartz tube and pretreated under He atmosphere at 400 °C for 1 h. After cooling down to 100 °C, the sample was exposed with NH3 for 30 min, followed by sweeping with a He flow for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. Then, the NH3-TPD profile was recorded under a He flow by heating the temperature to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The acid type of catalyst was measured by infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) using a Thermo Fisher infrared spectrometer (Nicolet 3800). Prior to pyridine adsorption, the sample was degassed under high vacuum at 400 °C for 3 h, then the corresponding background spectrum for the adsorbed pyridine determination was recorded after cooling down the sample to 30 °C. After that, the sample was exposed to pyridine for 30 min, and subsequent heated to 150 °C for pyridine evacuation for 1 h. Then, the corresponding infrared spectra was recorded. The nature and amount of coke in the spent catalyst were determined by temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) on the same TPD apparatus. In a typical procedure, 100 mg of deactivated catalyst was maintained at 200 °C for 1 h in a He stream, then it was cooled down to room temperature. After that, the TPO measurement was carried out in a 60 mL min−1 5% O2/He flow from 50 °C to 800 °C at a ramp of 10 °C min−1. 2.3 Catalytic tests The reaction of glycerol to aromatics (GTA) was performed in a fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm and a length of 40 cm. In a typical run, 1.2 g of the crushed catalyst (40–60 mesh) was loaded into the middle constant temperature zone of the reactor and pretreated at 400 °C for 30 min. After that, the glycerol/methanol mixture (40 wt% of glycerol) was syringed into the reactor by a LabAlliance series II pump with liquid weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.83 h−1, then the GTA reaction was carried out at 400 °C and 0.1 MPa. The gaseous products were analyzed by an online GC (Gas chromatography, GC-126 N, Shanghai Yidian Techcomp Ltd.) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a 5 A molecular sieve column, and with a flame ionization detector (FID) with carbon molecular sieve column and a modified alumina column. The liquid products were condensed in a cold trap and analyzed using an Ouhua gas chromatograph (GC-7890) with a flame ionization detector (FID) connected to a capillary column (SE-30, 30 m × 0.5 µm × 0.32 mm). Chlorobenzene was added to the liquid sample (0.1 g/g), and it was used as the internal standard (IS) to quantify the products. The reactant conversion and product yield were calculated by the following formulas: Conversion ( wt % ) = ( 1 − Mass of glycerol or methanol ( out ) Mass of glycerol or methanol ( in ) ) × 100 % Product yield wt % = Mass of a specific product Mass of the feedstock × 100 % Conversion C % = Moles of carbon in converted glycerol or methanol Moles of carbon in the feedstock × 100 % Product yield C % = Moles of carbon in a specific product Moles of carbon in the feedstock × 100 % Carban balance C % = Moles of carbon ( out ) Moles of carbon ( in ) × 100 % The analysis of gas products was not carried out in detail in this work since the liquid products, aromatics in particular, were the main focus. The external mass transfer limitation was estimated by exploring the influences of flow rate of feedstock on catalytic activity (Fig. S5), and the internal mass transfer limitations was estimated by studying the influences of size of crushed catalysts on catalytic activity (Fig. S6). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evolution of the 0.45-ZF/ZM-y with crystallization time The evolution of the structure and morphology of the 0.45-ZF/ZM-y samples prepared at different crystallization periods were interpreted by XRD, SEM and N2 adsorption-desorption. As shown in the XRD patterns ( Fig. 1a), only two weak and broad diffraction bands at about 2θ= 5–9 ° and 22–28 ° were found for the 0.45-ZF/ZM-1 and 0.45-ZF/ZM-3 samples, suggesting that the samples obtained during the first 3 h were almost amorphous phase [36]. After hydrothermal treatment for 5 h, the intensity of the diffraction peaks attributed to MFI zeolite dramatically increased and the relative crystallinity of 0.45-ZF/ZM-5 increased to 45% (Fig. 1b), which indicated that numerous of ZSM-5 zeolite crystals were generated rapidly during 3–5 h. Upon further extending the crystallization time to 24 h and 48 h, the crystallinity of 0.45-ZF/ZM-y further increased and the relative crystallinity of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 reached to 100%. It demonstrated that the transformation of amorphous aluminosilicate to highly crystalline MFI framework was gradually carried out during this stage. When the crystallization time was prolonged from 48 h to 60 h, no obvious change in crystallinity was found, suggesting that 48 h was appropriate for complete crystallization. The crystallization of 0.45-ZF/ZM-y samples was also monitored by SEM. As shown in Fig. 2a, ZIF-8 possessed a regular bulk morphology with particle size of 400–800 nm. After addition of aluminosilicate precursors and stirring at 25 °C for 24 h, numerous of amorphous species were observed in the samples (Fig. 2b). Meanwhile, some amorphous gels attached on the surface and gap of ZIF-8 particles were also observed in this stage (Fig. 2c), and the nucleation and crystallization of zeolite might be influenced by the ZIF-8 for confinement effect. After hydrothermal treatment for 3 h, as shown in Fig. 3d, most of the samples still existed as amorphous phase, which accorded with the XRD results. However, after hydrothermal treatment for 5 h, the morphology of the samples transformed from amorphous to regular globular aggregates obviously. As the crystallization time was further prolonged to 48 h, the globular zeolite particles of 200–400 nm that comprised of nanocrystals with size of 20–40 nm were obtained, and the amorphous species were completely consumed. The N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distributions of 0.45-ZF/ZM-y samples are shown in Fig. 3, and the corresponding pore textural properties are listed in Table 1. The 0.45-ZF/ZM-1 sample exhibited type-I isotherm with a significant uptake at low relative pressure (P/Po < 0.1), indicating that the sample was microporous material at the initial crystallization stage. Combined with the textural properties of 0.45-ZF/ZM-1 and ZIF-8 (entries 1–2, Table 1), it could be inferred that the 0.45-ZF/ZM-1 sample might be composed of amorphous aluminosilicate and undecomposed ZIF-8, which was consistent with the SEM results (Fig. 2c). After crystallization for 3 h, 0.45-ZF/ZM-3 showed type-IV isotherm with a H1 hysteresis loops at P/Po of 0.4–0.8. In contrast, 0.45-ZF/ZM-5 possessed type-IV isotherm with a H3 hysteresis loops at P/Po of 0.7–1. Additionally, the pore volume of 0.45-ZF/ZM-5 increased dramatically, which could be ascribed to the formation of inter-pores between amorphous aluminosilicate (Fig. 3b, Table 1). Further extending the crystallization time to 12–48 h, the samples exhibited type-IV isotherms with usual H3 hysteresis loops without obvious changes compared with 0.45-ZF/ZM-5. The evolution of hysteresis loops indicated that the pore structure of 0.45-ZF/ZM-y samples transformed significantly in the initial stages (1–5 h), while it changed slightly during the crystallization time of 5–48 h, which accorded with the SEM results. Moreover, the mesoporous volume of 0.45-ZF/ZM-y decreased from 0.886 to 0.506 cm3/g during 5–48 h, suggesting the order of the samples was enhanced along with crystallization, which could be related to that the amorphous aluminosilicate was transformed to crystalline MFI zeolite gradually. Especially, the microporous volume increased obviously, which also proved the crystallinity of 0.45-ZF/ZM-y was strengthened. According to the aforementioned results, the crystallization process of 0.45-ZF/ZM-y samples could be summarized in two stages. During the initial attachment-impregnation stage (1–3 h), the amorphous aluminosilicate precursor gradually attached on the surface and impregnated into the interior of the ZIF-8 particles. Then, during the stage of crystallization (3–48 h), the aluninosilicate gel loaded on the structure of ZIF-8 gradually transformed into nanosized HZSM-5 and aggregated together into globular particles due to the high surface energy of nanocrystals [38,39]. 3.2 The effect of the amount of ZIF-8 Fig. 4 presents the XRD patterns of the x-ZF/ZM-48 and conventional HZSM-5 catalysts. As can be seen, all samples displayed similar diffraction peaks with the pattern of typical MFI zeolite [11]. It indicated that the addition of ZIF-8 template had little influence on the framework structure of the resultant x-ZF/ZM-48 zeolites. However, the intensities of characteristic diffraction peaks in the Zn-containing HZSM-5, especially in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48, decreased compared with conventional HZSM-5, which might be ascribed to the decrease of crystallinity in these zeolite, as shown in Table S1. It indicated that the addition of ZIF-8 had significant influences on the crystallization of x-ZF/ZM-48 zeolite. In addition, no ZnO characteristic peaks at 31.8° and 36.3° could be discriminated from the XRD patterns of the Zn-containing HZSM-5 (Fig. 1b), suggesting the Zn species was highly dispersed in these zeolites [16,40]. As shown in Fig. 5, the Zn(2p3/2) XPS spectra of 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, 0.45-ZF/ZM-48, 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 and pure ZnO were determined to explore the chemical state and distribution of the surface Zn species in the prepared Zn-containing HZSM-5 catalysts. By fitting the Zn(2p3/2) XPS spectra, two peaks of Zn species with binding energies at about 1022.7 eV and 1023.7 eV were discriminated in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 and 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, suggesting that two types of Zn species were identified in these Zn-containing HZSM-5 catalysts. Taking into account that the pure ZnO exhibited a peak at 1021.6 eV, it was reasonable to assign the higher binding energy peak around 1022.7 eV in the Zn-containing catalysts to the ZnO species [15,41]. The obvious shift of the peak for ZnO species to higher binding energy was probably attributed to the effect of zeolite framework on ZnO species due to the much stronger electronegativity in HZSM-5 framework than that in O2- group [42,43]. On the other hand, the higher binding energy peak at about 1023.7 eV suggested the existence of Zn species possessing tight interaction with the HZSM-5 substrate framework [16]. Similar results were observed in the report by Chen and co-workers, the higher binding energy peak was attributed to the ZnOH+ species, which was formed from the strong interaction between the Zn species and the inherent protonic acid sites in HZSM-5 substrate [43]. In addition, the state and composition of surface Zn species in the Zn-containing HZSM-5 catalysts were obviously influenced by the addition amount of ZIF-8 template, as revealed by XPS results (Fig. 5). In 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, about 83.5% of surface Zn species existed as ZnOH+, whereas only 16.5% of Zn species was presented as ZnO. As the ZIF-8 amount was increased to 0.45 g, the portion of ZnOH+ species decreased to 80.6%, and the portion of ZnO species increased to 19.4% in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. Along with the ZIF-8 amount reached to 0.6 g, the ZnOH+ species fraction further decreased to 68.2% and the ZnO fraction increased to 31.8% in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48. It indicated that the ZnOH+ species on the surface of x-ZF/ZM-48 was reduced, whereas the ZnO species was enriched with the increase of ZIF-8 dosage. Moreover, as listed in Table 2, the surface content and bulk content of Zn in x-ZF/ZM-48 were measured by XPS and ICP, respectively, which indicated that the distribution of Zn species in x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts was also affected by ZIF-8 dosage. For 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 and 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, the surface Zn contents were much higher than the corresponding bulk ones, suggesting that the Zn species in these catalysts were concentrated on the zeolite surface. Nevertheless, for 0.45-ZF/ZM-48, the surface Zn content was just slight higher than the bulk one, indicating more Zn species in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 entered into the zeolite channels compared with that in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 and 0.6-ZF/ZM-48. This could probably ascribe to that the smaller crystal size of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 leaded to a shorter diffusion path for Zn species, which resulted in more Zn species accessed to the zeolite channels. The morphologies and structures of the conventional HZSM-5 and x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts were characterized by TEM. As shown in Figs. 6a and b, the conventional HZSM-5 exhibited a uniform cuboid morphology with a crystallite size of about 200–400 nm. However, both the morphologies and crystallite sizes of the prepared x-ZF/ZM-48 changed evidently after addition of ZIF-8 template in the zeolite synthesis process. As can be seen in Figs. 6c and 6d, a large amount of smaller nanocrystals with crystallite size of 50–100 nm were observed in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 besides the bulky crystals with crystal size of 200–400 nm, which suggested that the ZIF-8 template could induce the nucleation and crystallization process of zeolite to form smaller nanocrystals. Furthermore, obvious aggregations of the smaller nanocrystals were found, and some stacking and connection between nanocrystals and bulky crystals were also appeared in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, which was due to the high surface energy of the nanocrystals [38,39]. This might be responsible for the formation of inter-crystalline mesopores in the x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts. As ZIF-8 amount was increased to 0.45 g, the obtained 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 exhibited as globular particles of 200–400 nm, which were aggregated from small nanocrystals of about 20–40 nm, and no bulky cuboid crystals of 200–400 nm was observed in this catalyst (Figs. 6e and 6f). In addition, the aggregations of nanocrystals in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 were more obviously than that in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, which were probably resulted from the smaller size of nanocrystals in the former zeolite. However, as shown in Figs. 6g and 6h, when the ZIF-8 amount was increased to 0.6 g, the bulky crystals of 200–400 nm reappeared in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, and nanocrystals of 30–50 nm was found simultaneously. Furthermore, the stacking and connection of the two types of crystals in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 were inconspicuous. This could probably be ascribed to the destructive effect of excessive ZIF-8 template on nucleation and crystallization of zeolite, which would lead to a conspicuous phase separation of bulky crystals and small nanocrystals in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 zeolite. Moreover, no obvious ZnO particles was observed in the TEM images of all x-ZF/ZM-48 samples, indicating Zn species were dispersed completely in these Zn-containing zeolites, which accorded with the XRD results. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of conventional HZSM-5 and x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts were shown in Fig. 7a. As can be seen, all the isotherms exhibited a sharp increase at low relative pressures (P/Po < 0.1) and a hysteresis loop at high relative pressures (P/Po=0.8–1), suggesting the co-existence of inherent micropores and mesopores in these catalysts [20]. In addition, the hysteresis loops in x-ZF/ZM-48 were more obvious than that in conventional HZSM-5, which indicated that the addition of ZIF-8 was helpful for the formation of mesopores. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distributions of the as-prepared catalysts using the adsorption branch of the isotherms are shown in Fig. 7b. Compared with conventional HZSM-5 possessed inconspicuous inter-macropores with size of 50–100 nm, 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 and 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 exhibited inter-mesopores mainly located at 20–50 nm, while 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 had inter-macropores mainly located at 50–100 nm. Furthermore, the quantity of inter-crystalline pores in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 decreased dramatically compared with 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 and 0.45-ZF/ZM-48, and this might weaken its catalytic performance for limiting the diffusion of bulky molecules. The textural properties of conventional HZSM-5 and x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts were listed in Table 2. As shown, the addition of ZIF-8 had significant influences on the surface areas and pore volumes of x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts. The external surface area and mesopore volume of 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 increased compared with conventional HZSM-5, which was ascribed to the smaller zeolite nanocrystals induced by ZIF-8 and the inter-crystalline mesopores formed by nanocrystal aggregation. Furthermore, as the ZIF-8 amount was increased to 0.45 g, the obtained 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 exhibited a larger mesopore volume and a smaller external surface area compared with 0.3-ZF/ZM-48. This was owing to the complete aggregation of nanocrystals in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 to bulky globular particles, which resulted in the formation of numerous inter-mesopores and reduced external surface area. The nanocrystals were beneficial to the diffusion of bulky reagents and products in zeolite channels for shortened diffusion path [24], and the inter-mesopores could provide enough space to resist coke and prevent the quick blocking of micropore entrances [28], which would effectively alleviate the deactivation of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 in GTA reaction. However, when the ZIF-8 addition was further increased to 0.6 g, the mesopore volume decreased while the external surface area increased to some extent in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, which was related to the reappearance of bulky crystals and the phase separation of bulky crystals and small nanocrystals resulted from the excessive of ZIF-8 template. Moreover, the micropore volumes of x-ZF/ZM-48 decreased compared with conventional HZSM-5, which was owing to the partial Zn species entered in the zeolite channels, as revealed by ICP-OES and XPS results. Nevertheless, it should be noted that majority of the micropores in x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts were reserved, indicating the high crystallinities of these zeolites were not severely destroyed by ZIF-8. The acidic properties of conventional HZSM-5 and x-ZF/ZM-48 were determined by NH3-TPD, as shown in Fig. 8 and Table 3. The acid sites distributions based on acidic strength was distinguished by deconvolution of the NH3-TPD profiles [44], as shown in Fig. 8, where the amounts of weak, medium and strong acid sites were calculated by the quantities of NH3 desorption peak centred around 211, 302 and 448 °C, respectively. The addition of ZIF-8 also had significant influence on the acidic distribution of x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts. As shown, compared with conventional HZSM-5, the amount of medium acid sites in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 increased remarkably, whereas the corresponding strong and weak acid sites decreased obviously. It should be related to that partial introduced Zn species situated on the external surface and in the zeolite channels interacted with the intrinsic strong acid sites in the zeolite substrate and converted these reduced acid sites into the new Zn-based medium acid sites [45]. In addition, the increase of ZIF-8 dosage from 0.3 g to 0.45 g resulted in the further decrease of strong acid sites and weak acid sites, and further increase of medium acid sites in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. As the ZIF-8 amount was increased to 0.6 g, the strong acid amount decreased to 0.428 mmol/g and the medium acid amount increased to 0.367 mmol/g in 0.6-ZF/HZSM-5, which was very different with the strong acid amount (0.641 mmol/g) and medium acid amount (0.083 mmol/g) in conventional HZSM-5. The amount of medium acid sites increased in the order of HZSM-5 < 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 < 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 < 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, which suggested that the Zn-based medium acid sites of x-ZF/ZM-48 were close related to the ZIF-8 dosage. Additionally, in consideration of that the acidic properties had important influence on the zeolite catalytic performances, it meant that the catalytic performances of the obtained catalysts could also be regulated by the change of ZIF-8 dosage. Fig. 9. shows the infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) over the prepared conventional HZSM-5 and x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts. Two characteristic peaks around 1545 cm−1 and 1454 cm−1, related to the Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites, respectively, were observed in all of the catalysts [41,46]. The quantitative analysis of Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites in the prepared catalysts are listed in Table 4. As shown, compared with conventional HZSM-5, the number of Lewis acid sites in x-ZF/ZM-48 increased obviously at the expense of the corresponding Brønsted acid sites with the introduction of ZIF-8 template. It could be attributed to that the introduced Zn species interacted with the Brønsted acid sites in x-ZF/ZM-48 substrate and converted partial Brønsted acid sites into Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+), which further improved the L/B ratio of these Zn-containing catalysts [40,41]. In addition, the Brønsted acid sites in x-ZF/ZM-48 decreased whereas the corresponding Lewis acid sites increased with the increase of ZIF-8 dosage, thus the L/B ratio followed the sequence of HZSM-5 < 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 < 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 < 0.6-ZF/ZM-48. Interestingly, this sequence was consistent with that of the amount of medium acid sites (Table 3), which indicated that the new medium acid sites might originate from Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+) resulting from the interaction between the introduced Zn species and the Brønsted acid sites in x-ZF/ZM-48 substrate. Besides, the redistribution of Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites could regulate the synergistic effects of these two types of active sites, which might further affect the catalytic performances of x-ZF/ZM-48. 3.3 Catalytic performances of conventional HZSM-5 and x-ZF/ZM-48 Figs. 10 and 11 illustrate the catalytic performances of conventional HZSM-5 and x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts in the glycerol to aromatics (GTA) reaction. As shown in Fig. 10, the main products in GTA reaction could be classified into four groups: generated water, gas fragments (containing alkene, alkane, H2, COx), aromatics (including BTX, trimethylbenzene/methylethylbenzene (C9), durene (C10+)), and liquid oxycarbides (including acrolein, acetol, propanal, acetone, aldehyde, et al.). The complex product distribution was due to the complicated GTA process over HZSM-5 catalyst, which was composed of multistep parallel and tandem reactions, as presented in Scheme 1 [2,21]. The glycerol feedstock was first transformed into acrolein and acetol intermediates through dehydration reaction, and the generated intermediates were further converted into other oxycarbides (propanal, acetone, aldehyde, propanol) via hydrogenation, dehydration, hydrogen transfer and cracking reactions. Subsequently, part of the oxycarbides (propanal, acetone, aldehyde) was converted into C9 aromatics through aldol condensation and cyclization reactions (liquid route), in which the oxygen in the oxycarbides was removed in the modality of H2O. In the meantime, partial oxycarbides was first transformed into alkenes through decarbonylation/deoxygenation/cracking reactions and then converted into BTX via oligomerization and aromatization reactions (gas route), in which the oxygen in the oxycarbides was transformed into COx. As shown in Fig. 10 and Table S4, 24.4% BTX yield, 32.5% total aromatics yield, and 7.1% C9 yield were obtained over conventional HZSM-5. The catalytic activities of x-ZF/ZM-48 were enhanced significantly for the promotion effects of the introduced Zn species on GTA reaction after the addition of ZIF-8 during zeolite synthesis process. In 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, both BTX yield (38.5%) and C9 yield (10.6%) improved remarkably, and this leaded to a significant improvement of total aromatics yield (52.2%) compared with conventional HZSM-5. On the one hand, the generated Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+) in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 by the addition of ZIF-8 could effectively promote the dehydrogenation-aromatization step in the gas route during GTA reaction, which would lead to a remarkable improvement in the BTX yield [4,16]. On the other hand, the new formed Lewis acid sites in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 was helpful to the aldol condensation step in the liquid route, which could result in more C9 aromatics [47], as shown in Table S5. Besides, as revealed by TEM result, the introduced ZIF-8 could induce the formation of smaller zeolite nanocrystals and inter-crystalline mesopores in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, and this shortened the diffusion path of products in zeolite channels, which could facilitate the diffusion of bulky intermediates out from the channels and thus result in more C9+ products over 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 catalyst (13.6%). As the ZIF-8 dosage was increased to 0.45 g, more Zn-Lewis acid sites were formed while reserving certain amount of strong acid sites in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48, which further enhanced the aldol condensation step in the liquid route, and thus the C9 yield improved markedly to 13.4%. Meanwhile, as all the 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was smaller nanocrystal and formed more inter-crystalline mesopores, the diffusion of bulky products in this catalyst was further enhanced and the shape selectivity effect of zeolite micropores was further weakened compared with 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, which resulted in more C9+ larger aromatics (22.5%) and total aromatics (59.5%) over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. When the ZIF-8 dosage was increased to 0.6 g, the amount of Zn-Lewis acid sites was continued to increase in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, which further enhanced the dehydrogenation-aromatization step in the gas route. However, the amount of strong acid sites that required for oligomerization/cyclization steps decreased dramatically in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, which resulted in some inhibition on the alkene oligomerization/cyclization steps in gas route, and thus the BTX yield in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 was not obviously improved compared with 0.45-ZF/HZSM-5 [15]. Furthermore, although the abundant medium Zn-Lewis acid sites in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 could effectively facilitate the aldol condensation steps in liquid route, the diffusion of larger C9+ aromatics in zeolite channels was severely restricted due to the reappearance of bulky zeolite crystals, and thus the C9+ aromatics yield decreased to 16.9%. Accordingly, the total aromatics yield decreased to 55.1% over 0.6-ZF/ZM-48. Based on the above analysis, the improved BTX yield in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 could be attributed to the formed Zn-Lewis acid sites and the suitable reserved strong acid sites, which would facilitate the dehydrogenation/aromatization and oligomerization/cyclization steps in gas route, simultaneously. Besides, the higher C9+ yield in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was due to the synergy of the Lewis acid sites and the small nanocrystals. On the one hand, the generated Lewis acid enhanced the aldol condensation step in the liquid route, which could promote the formation of more C9. On the other hand, the diffusion of formed larger C9+ aromatics in the zeolite channels could be facilitated by the smaller nanocrystals of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 for shorter diffusion path and less steric constrains. Consequently, a superior total aromatics yield (59.5%) was obtained in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. Moreover, the catalytic performance of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was also more superior than that of nanosized Zn/HZSM-5(IM) (48.3% aromatics yield and 5.0 h lifetime, as listed in Table S2) prepared by conventional impregnation method and nanosized Zn/HZSM-5(PM) (46.6% aromatics yield and 6.5 h lifetime) by physical mixing method. It could be ascribed to the synergistic effect among the ZnOH+ species, inter-crystalline mesopores and nanocrystals in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 catalyst. Therefore, compared with other synthesis method, such as post-synthesis modification, impregnation and Zn ion-exchange, the current Zn-based MOFs template method was more convenient and efficient. On the one hand, ZnOH+ species and mesopores could be simultaneously introduced in the prepared x-ZF/ZM-48 zeolite by just addition of ZIF-8 in zeolite synthesis process, which could effectively improve aromatics yield and catalytic lifetime of x-ZF/ZM-48 through one-step method. On the other hand, the addition of ZIF-8 induced the generation of small zeolite nanocrystals with shortened diffusion path, which further improved the catalytic performances of x-ZF/ZM-48 by promoting the diffusion of bulky molecules and decreasing the coke formation rate in GTA reaction. In addition, as shown in Fig. 10 and Fig. 11, the 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 exhibited a much longer catalyst lifetime (defined as the time at which the BTX yield was lower than 10% in this work) compared with other catalysts, indicating this catalyst also possessed outstanding catalytic stability simultaneously. 3.4 Improved catalytic stability of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 As can be seen in Fig. 11, the catalyst lifetime of conventional HZSM-5 was only 3.5 h, whereas that of 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 and 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 was 8.5 h, 11.0 h and 7.0 h, respectively. It suggested that the introduction of ZIF-8 in the zeolite synthesis could prolong the lifetimes of x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts, and the ZIF-8 dosage had significant influences on the catalyst lifetimes and catalytic stabilities of these catalysts. The textural properties of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 used at different time on stream were listed in Table 5. As shown, the BET surface area and pore volume of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 were decreased gradually with time on stream. Notably, the internal surface area and microporous volume disappeared completely, and the external surface area and mesoporous volume reduced dramatically when the 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was deactivated after 11 h on-stream. It could be owing to the fact that the formed coke deposited ceaselessly on the zeolite external surfaces and channels, which covered part of active acid sites and blocked partial channels and micropore entrances of zeolite, resulting in the gradual decline of catalytic activity [41]. Furthermore, the textural properties and structural properties of regenerated 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 obtained by elimination of coke were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption and XRD, as shown in Table 5 and Fig. 12. Compared with fresh 0.45-ZF/ZM-48, the surface area and pore volume of Re-0.45-ZF/ZM-48 were almost recovered, and the framework structure of the catalyst was well preserved, indicating that both porous structure and framework structure of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 were not destroyed irreversibly in the deactivation process. In conclusion, the deactivation of the fresh catalysts in GTA reaction was largely ascribed to the severe blockage of zeolite channels and micropore entrances by the deposited coke. Consequently, the nature and amount of the coke in the deactivated catalysts were determined by TPO. As illustrated by Fig. 13 and Table 6, the deactivated catalysts exhibited a dominant peak at higher temperature around 660 °C along with a weak peak at lower temperature around 402 °C, which were ascribed to the decomposition of hydrogen-deficient insoluble coke and hydrogen-rich soluble coke formed in GTA reaction, respectively [15,21]. The high temperature range peak of x-ZF/ZM-48 shifted to lower temperature with the increase of ZIF-8 dosage, which could be attributed to that the polymerization degree of coke formed in x-ZF/ZM-48 was reduced with the increase of ZIF-8, as the Brønsted acid sites relating to coke formation rate was gradually decreased with increasing ZIF-8 dosage, thus leading to lower temperature required for burning coke over x-ZF/ZM-48 with more ZIF-8 dosage. In addition, as shown in Table 6, the total amount of coke over the used 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 (11368 total area in TPO for 11 h on-stream) was much higher than that over the used conventional HZSM-5 (9615 total area in TPO for 3.5 h), indicating that the accommodation ability of coke over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was stronger than conventional HZSM-5. Furthermore, the average coke formation rate was expressed with the corresponding total area in TPO per hour. As calculated in Table 6, the average coke formation rate over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was only 1033 h−1, which was much lower than 2747 h−1 over conventional HZSM-5, and this should be responsible for the much longer catalyst lifetime of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. In addition, to further explore the reasons for stronger coke accommodation ability and lower coke formation rate over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48, the textural properties of the deactivated 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 and deactivated conventional HZSM-5 were studied in detail. As depicted in Table 5, the mesoporous volume of deactivated 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 decreased markedly compared with fresh 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 (26.3% reduction), whereas that of deactivated conventional HZSM-5 only decreased slightly compared with fresh HZSM-5 (5.4% reduction), which suggested that the coke over conventional HZSM-5 was inclined to deposit in the zeolite micropore while certain amounts of coke over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 were deposited in the mesopores apart from micropores. It could be attributed to the smaller nanocrystals and the resulting inter-crystalline mesopores formed by the aggregation of these nanocrystals in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. On the one hand, the smaller 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 nanocrystals with shortened diffusion path facilitated the diffusion of bulky molecules in the zeolite channels, and this effectively reduced the accumulation of large molecular coke precursors and inhibited the serious blockage of micropores, which further reduced the coke formation rate in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 catalyst [24]. On the other hand, compared with micropores, the formed inter-crystalline mesopores could provide much more space to accommodate coke that similar to intra-crystalline mesopores, which enhanced the coke resistance and slowed down the deactivation of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. As a consequence, 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 presented much higher catalytic stability than the conventional HZSM-5. The influences of ZIF-8 dosage on the catalytic stability were also investigated to thoroughly understand the deactivation mechanisms of x-ZF/ZM-48 catalysts. Compared with conventional HZSM-5, some small nanocrystals and inter-crystalline mesopores with size of 20–50 nm were formed in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48, thus the diffusion of large molecular products was enhanced and the deposition of coke was suppressed in this catalyst. Moreover, partial strong Brønsted acid sites in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 was converted into Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+) through the tight interaction between the introduced Zn species and the intrinsic strong Brønsted acid sites in the zeolite substrate, which might slow down the coke formation rate, as the coke deposition was closely related to Brønsted acid sites [48,49]. However, due to the fact that only a small amount of mesopores was generated in zeolite and the formed Zn-Lewis acid sites was helpful to the production of more C9 larger aromatics via aldol condensation step in liquid route, the coke formation rate in 0.3-ZF/ZM-48 was still quite high (1531 h−1). As the ZIF-8 dosage was increased to 0.45 g, the obtained 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 all existed as smaller nanocrystals with crystallite size of 20–40 nm and more inter-crystalline mesopores of 20–50 nm were formed, which could effectively enhance the diffusion of large molecular reagents and products in zeolite channels and further significantly slow down the coke formation rate in the catalyst. Additionally, 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 possessed suitable distributions of acid strength and acid type by the addition of moderate ZIF-8, which could further improve the total aromatics yield and reduce the coke formation rate by coordinating the gas route and liquid route in GTA reaction. Besides, the higher mesoporous volume in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 promoted the coke accommodation obviously, which could further reduce the deactivation of the catalyst. As a result, 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 exhibited a lower coke formation rate (1033 h−1) and a longer catalyst lifetime (11 h). When the ZIF-8 amount was increased to 0.6 g, numerous of bulky crystals reappeared accompany with small nanocrystals and the quantity of inter-crystalline macropores of 50–100 nm reduced markedly, which accelerated the coke formation rate and weakened the coke accommodation of 0.6-ZF/ZM-48. In addition, more C9+ coke precursors were formed due to the further increase of Zn-Lewis acid sites in 0.6-ZF/ZM-48, leading to a faster deactivation of the catalyst. Consequently, 0.6-ZF/ZM-48 showed decreased catalytic stability with only 7 h lifetime. On the basis of the above results, the outstanding stability of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 could be associated to the smaller nanocrystals, more inter-crystalline mesopores, and suitable acidic properties resulted from the proper addition of ZIF-8 in the zeolite synthesis procedure. 3.5 Catalytic mechanism of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 The catalytic mechanism of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was deduced based on the aforementioned results and related literature, as revealed in Scheme 2. The addition of ZIF-8 in the zeolite synthesis induced the formation of small nanocrystals and the resulting inter-crystalline mesopores. As the ZIF-8 amount reached to 0.45 g, the obtained 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 was totally comprised of nanocrystals with size of 20–40 nm, and numerous inter-crystalline mesopores were formed by the aggregation of these nanocrystals. Meanwhile, this catalyst possessed suitable distribution of strong acid sites and Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+), which could effectively enhance the dehydrogenation-aromatization steps in gas route and the aldol condensation step in liquid step simultaneously, resulting in higher BTX yield and C9 yield over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48. Furthermore, the substantial inter-crystalline mesopores in this catalyst significantly facilitated the diffusion of large molecules and dramatically weakened the steric constraint of micropores, leading to a large amount of C9+ aromatics. Moreover, the nanocrystals in 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 with shortened diffusion path could promote the diffusion of bulky molecules and thus slow down the coke formation rate, and the formed inter-crystalline mesopores could enhance the coke accommodation, which ultimately slowed down the deactivation process and improved the catalytic stability. Taking the above into consideration, it was reasonable to ascribe the superior catalytic activity and stability of 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 to the synergy among the Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+), inter-crystalline mesopores and HZSM-5 nanocrystals. 4 Conclusions A series of nanosized x-ZF/ZM-y zeolites were prepared by changing the crystallization time and ZIF-8 template amount in the zeolite synthesis process. The results indicated that the growth of x-ZF/ZM-y involved two stages. In the initial attachment-impregnation stage, the amorphous aluminosilicate precursor attached on the surface and impregnated into the interior of the ZIF-8 particles. Next, in the following crystallization stage, the aluminosilicate gel loaded on the structure of ZIF-8 gradually transformed into nanosized HZSM-5 and finally formed globular aggregates comprised of nanocrystals with size of 20–40 nm after complete crystallization. The obtained catalysts exhibited superior catalytic activity and higher stability compared with conventional HZSM-5 in the GTA reaction, which was owing to the coinstantaneous presence of active Zn species, smaller HZSM-5 nanocrystals and inter-crystalline mesopores in x-ZF/ZM-48 through the addition of ZIF-8. The introduced Zn species in x-ZF/ZM-48 transformed partial intrinsic Brønsted acid sites into Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+), which could enhance the dehydrogenation-aromatization and aldol condensation steps in GTA reaction, and thus improve the aromatics yield. Furthermore, the generated nanocrystals in x-ZF/ZM-48 with shortened diffusion path significantly facilitate the diffusion of bulky molecules, which could not only slow down the coke formation rate, but also improve the C9+ aromatics yield. Moreover, the simultaneously formed inter-crystalline mesopores could enhance the coke accommodation, which further slowed down the deactivation process and prolonged the catalyst lifetime of x-ZF/ZM-48. In particular, as the ZIF-8 dosage was increased to 0.45 g, the obtained 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 existed as nanocrystals with crystallite size of 20–40 nm homogeneously, and it possessed an appropriate redistribution of acid strength and acid type. As a result, nearly 100% carbon conversion and 59.5% aromatics yield as well as 11 h catalyst lifetime were obtained over the nanosized 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 catalyst owing to the synergistic effect among the Zn-Lewis acid sites (ZnOH+), inter-crystalline mesopores and HZSM-5 nanocrystals. However, excessive ZIF-8 might introduce too much Zn species and destroy the crystallization of zeolite, which would decrease the aromatics yield and catalyst lifetime of 0.6-ZF/ZM-48. coredata.dc:description: A series of novel nanosized x-ZF/ZM-y zeolites for glycerol to aromatics (GTA) were synthesized by using ZIF-8 as a template. The crystallization time and ZIF-8 dosage were systematically studied to clarify the crystallization process, structural characteristics and physicochemical properties of the prepared x-ZF/ZM-y. The results indicated that the growth of x-ZF/ZM-y zeolites involved two stages: attachment-impregnation and crystallization. The addition of ZIF-8 could introduce the active Zn species (ZnOH+) and induce the formation of smaller HZSM-5 nanocrystals in x-ZF/ZM-y, which could effectively facilitate the dehydrogenation-aromatization and aldol condensation steps in GTA and enhance the coke resistance. Furthermore, the ZIF-8 dosage had important influences on the catalytic performances of x-ZF/ZM-y. In particular, the 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 with 0.45 g ZIF-8 dosage and 48 h crystallization time all existed as nanocrystals of 20–40 nm, and possessed a proper redistribution of acid sites, resulting in 59.5% total aromatics yield and 11 h catalyst lifetime over 0.45-ZF/ZM-48 owing to the synergistic effect among the ZnOH+, inter-crystalline mesopores and HZSM-5 nanocrystals.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient conversion of glycerol to aromatics over stable nanosized x-ZF/ZM-y catalysts using ZIF-8 as a template
